VXVII. 25 29
I ^ here Foundfound an insect which preys
on ants - It is about an inch
and a quarter long as thick
as a crow quill and covered
with black hair - It puts its
head into a little hole in the ground
and quivers its tail rapidly
the ants come near to see it
and it snaps up each as
he comes within range of
the forceps on hisits tail - As
his its head was beneath the
ground it became a question
how heit could guide hisits tail
to the ants - On first observing
this feat I imagined the
forceps were on hisits head
but when the insect moved
the true ^ position relation was seen

The forest through which
we were slowly toiling daily
became more dense - and
we were kept almost con-
stantly at work with the axe
There was much more leafiness
in the trees here than farther
south - The leaves are chiefly
of the pinnate & bipinnate
forms and afford a fine
26 30
and are exceedingly beautiful
when seen against the sky
an great variety of the papilionaceous
family grow in this country
part of this country

25th - Fleming had untilluntil now
always assisted to [drive his
own waggon but now he
109 knocksed up as well as his
people As I could not drive
two waggons I partedshared the remaining
water with him (half a caskful)
and went on with the intention
of coming back for him as
soon as we should reach
the next pool - Heavy rain
now commenced - I was
employed the whole day in
cutting down trees and every
stroke of the axe brought down
a thick shower on my back
which in the hard work was
very refreshing as it ^ the water found
its way down into my the my shoes
In the evening we met some
Bushmen who volunteered
to shewshow us a pool & having
unyoked I walked some
miles in search of it. As
it became dark they shewedshowed
their politeness - a quality
which is
notby no means ^ confined
entirely to
the civilized by walking
in front and breaking
the branches of trees which
hung across the path and
pointing out the fallen trees
27 31
On returning we found that
being left alone had brought
out some of Fleming's energy
for he had managed to
come up

As the water in this pond
dried up we were obliged to
move on again - One of the Bushmen
took out their his dice and after throwing
them said - God told him to go
home = He threw again in order
to shewshow me the command but
the opposite was said, so he
remained and was useful
for we lost the oxen again
by a lion driving them off ^ to a
very great distance
The lions here are not often
heard - They seem to have a
wholesome dread of the Bushmen
who when they observe evidence
of ^ a lion's him having made a full
meal follow up his spoor
so quietly ^ that his slumbers are
not disturbed - One discharges
a poisoned arrow from
a distance of only a few feet
while his companion
simultaneously throws his
skin clokack on the beast's
head - The sudden surprise
makes him ^ the lion lose his presence
of mind and he bounds
away in the greatest confusion
and terror - Our friends
28 32
Our friends here shewedshowed me the
poison which they use on these
occasions - It is the entrails
of a caterpillar ½1/2 an inch long called N'gwa
They squeeze out these and
place them all around the
bottom of the barb and allow
the poison it to dry in the sun - They are
very careful in cleaning their
nails after working with it
as a small portion introduced
into a scratch acts like morbid
matter in dissection wounds
The agony is so great that
the person cuts himself - calls
for his mothersmother's breast as if
he were returned in idea to his
childhood again or flies
from human habitations
a raging maniac - The effects
on the lion in the case mentioned
are equally terrible - They hear
He is heard him moaning in distress
and he becomes furious
biting the trees and ground
in rage -

As the Bushmen have
the reputation of curing theise
wounds of this wpoison I asked how that this
was effected - They say said
that they administer the
caterpillar itself in combination
with fat fat They also rub
fat into the wound and addsaying that
29 33
"The N'gwa wants fat and when
it does not find it in the body
kills the man - We give it what
it wants and it is content" a
reason which will commend
itself to the enlightened among
ourselves -

The generally poison employed
is the milky juice of the
Euphorbia - This is particularly
obnoxious to the equine race
When a quantity is mixed
with the water of a pond
a whole herd will of zebras
will fall dead by the poison
before they have moved
away two miles - but it
does not kill oxen or man
On them it acts as It is a drastic purgative only
The same poison is used
all over the country though
in some places ^ ^ the poison of serpents and
a certain bulb are added in
order to increase the virulence
Father Pedro a Jesuit who
lived at Zumbo made a
balsam containing a number
of plants and castor oil
as a remedy for poisoned
arrow wounds - It is probable that
he derived his knowledge from
a similar source as I did
and that the reputed efficacy
of the balsam is owing to its
fatty constituent
30 34
In cases of the bites of serpents
a small key ought to be
pressed down firmly on the
wound - the orifice of the
key being applied to answering to the puncture
till suction be a cupping
glass can be got from one
of the natives - A watch
key pressed firmly on the
point stung by a scorpion
extracts the poison and
a mixture of fat or oil and
ppecacuan-haipecacuanha relieves the
pain

The Bushmen here are
generally fine well made men
and are nearly independantindependent
of everyone - They were
fond of a root somewhat
like a kidney potato and
the kernel of a nut which
Fleming thinks a kind of betel
The tree is a fine large spreading one,
and the leaves palmate
From the numbersquantities of berries
and ^ the number of game in these parts
the Bushmen they can scarcely ever be ill
badly off for food - As I could
without much difficulty
keep them well supplied
with meat and wished them
to remain I proposed that
they should bring their wives
to get a share but they remarked
that the women could always
31 35
take care of themselves -

None of the men ^ of our party had died but
two seemed unlikely to recover
and Kibopechoe my willing
Mokwain at last became
troubled with boils and then
got all the symptoms of fever
As he lay down the others
began to move about and
complained of weakness
only - Believing that frequent
change of place was conducive
to their recovery we moved
along as ^ much as we could untill
and came to the hill Ngwa which
being the only one we saw ^ had seen since
leaving the Bamangwato
we felt inclined to take off
our hats to it - It is three or
four hundred feet high and
covered with trees - As iIt'sIts
geographical position is
pretty accurately laid down
from an occultation and
other observations . I may
mention that the valley on
its northern side named Kandehy ^ is as picturesque is a fine
a little scenespot as is to be seen
in this part of Africa - An
open glade surrounded by
forest trees of various
hues has a little stream
meandering in the centre
A herd of reddish coloured
32 36
antelopes stood on one side near
a large Baobab looking at us and ready to run
up the hill - While some gnus
and Tsessebes and zebras
gazed in astonishment at
the intruders while some
fed carelessly
and others
put on the
peculiar air
of displeasure ^ which
these animals
sometimes
assume
before they
resolve on
flight - A large white
Rhinoceros came along the
bottom of the valley with his
slow sauntering gait without
noticing us - he looked as if
he meant to indulge in
a mud bath - While ^ severalSeveral buffaloes
with their dark visages stood
under the trees on the side
opposite to the Pallahs - It
being Sunday all was peace
and we could not but thinkreflect
from circum-
stances in
which theour
companyparty was
placed think ofon that
second stage of our existence immortal
lives which we hope will
^ lead us into scenes of perfect beauty
If freed from our guilt
in that perfectly free way
the bibleBible mentions death will
be a glorious thing - but to be
consigned to wait for the
Omit Judgement day with nothing
nothing else to ponder on
but those sins we shwould rather
forget is a grewsomegruesomea sad prosp prospect

Our bushmenBushmen wished to
leave and as there is no use
in trying to thwart these
Independantindependent gentlemen I
paid them and allowed them
to go - The payment however
33 379
having been made in the presence
of some strangers acted as a
charm and made them ^ these latter vol-
-unteer their aid - ⎡The game is
very tame - Khoodoos and
giraffe standstood gazing as I
sometimes went out with
the Bushmen - A lion came
at day break and went round
and round the oxen I could
only get a glimpse of him
occasionally from the waggon
box but though only 30 yards
off I could not get a shot -
He then began to roar at
the top of his voice but when
the oxen continued to stand
still - he was so disgusted ^ that he
went off and continued to
use his fo voice for a long
time in the distance - I could
not see whether he had a
QuQuery meaning. mane - but if he had ^ not then
even they ^ the maneless variety can find a use
for their tongues - We heard
others also near & when they
found they could not frighten
the the oxen they became equally angry
This we It could be observed in their
tones

As we went North the
country became very
lovely - Many new trees
appeared - The grass was
green & often higher than
34 38
and often higher than the waggon -
The vines festooned the trees
among which the real
banyan with its drops and
the wild date and Palmyra appeared
The valleys contained large
patches of water and several
others^ trees which were new to me
QuQuery To the pools succeeded
valleys ^ ^ or water courses resembling small
rivers 20 yards broad & four
feet deep - The farther we
went these valleys became
the broader and deeper, their
bottoms contained great
numbers of deep holes
made by elephants wading
in them In these the oxen
floundered desperately - In
one our waggon pole
broke and ^ compelling us to making work
up to the breast in water for
3 ½1/2 hours necessary - yet I suffered
no harm - We at last came
to the Sanshureh
which presented an impass-
able barrier so we drew
up under a magnificent
Baobab tree - and resolved
to explore ^ the river it for a ford
The great quantity of water
we had passed through
was part of the annual
inundation of the Chobe -
35 39
and this which appeared a
large riverdeep river filled in
many parts with reeds
and having hippopotami
in it is only one of the
branches by which it
sends it superabundant
water to the South East
From the hill Ngwa a
ridge of higher land runs
to the NorNorth East ^ and bounds
its flow in that direction
We being ignorant of this
were in the valley and
the only gap in the whole
country destitute of Tsetse
In company with the bushmenBushmen
I explored all the canal banks
of the Sanshureh to the west
till we came into tsetse
on that side - We waded
a long way among the
reeds up in water breast
deep but always found
a broad deep space of
water free from vegetation
and unfordable - A peculiar
kind of Lichen which grows
on the surface of the soil
becomes detached and
floats on the surface giving
out a very disagreeable odour
in some of these stagnant
waters - We made so many
36 40
attempts to get over the Sanshureh
^ both to the West
& East of the
waggon in the hope of reaching some
of the Makololo on the Chobe
that my bushmenBushmen friends
became quite tired of the
work - By ^ means of presents I got them
to remain some days but at
last they let meslipped away by night -
And I was fain to take one
of ^ the strongest of my still weak companions
and cross the river in a
pontoon the gift of Captains
Codrington and Webb - We each
carried some provisions and
a blanket - and passed away
about 20 miles to the Westwards
in the hope of cutting the Chobe
It was much nearer in the
North but this we did not then
know - The plain over which
we splashed the whole of the
first day was covered with
water ankle deep and ^ thick grass
which reached above the
knees - In the evening we
came to an immense wall
of reeds 6 or 8 feet high without
any opening admitting of a
passage - in when we tried
to enter the water always
became so deep that we
were fain to desist - We
concluded ^ that we had come
to the banks of the river we
37 41
were in search of - So we directed
our course to some trees which
appeared in the South in order
to get a bed and a view of
the adjacent locality - Having
shot a Leché and made
a glorious fire and afterwe got a good
a cup of tea weand had a com-
fortable night - While collecting
wood that
evening I
found a
nest made
of live leaves
sewn together
with threads
made of the
spidersspider's web
Nothing could
exceed the
airiness of
of this pretty
contrivance
The threads
had been pushed
through a small
punctures and
thickened to
resemble a knot
I unfortunately
lost it. This
iswas the second
I have seen

Next morning by climbing
the highest trees we could
see a fine large sheet of
water but surrounded on
all sides by the same impen-
-etrable belt of reeds - This
is the broad part named
Zabesa - Two tree [covered 113
islands seemed to be much
nearer to the water than
the shore on which we were
so we made an attempt to
get to them first - It was
not ^ the reeds alone ^ that we had to
get through; a peculiar serrated
grass which at certain
angles cut the hands like
a razor was mingled with
the reed and the climbing
convolvulus with stalks
which felt as strong as
whip cord bound the mass
together - We felt like pigmiespygmies
in it and often the only way
we could get on was by
38 42
both leaning against a part
and bending it down till we could
stand upon it - Strong moleskin
trousers The perspiration
streamed off our bodies and
as the sun rose the heat high
there being no ventilation the
heat was stifling - and the
water which was up to the
knees felt argreablyagreeably refreshing
After some hours toil we
reached the farthest off island
with my our strong moleskin trousers
worn through at the knees - hereHere we met
an old friend
viz.videlicet bramble
bushes.
those The leather trousers of my companion of
leather were also torn and
his legs bleeding - Tearing
my handkerchief in two
I tied them ^ the pieces round my knees
and then encountered another
difficulty - We were still fifty
forty or fifty yards from clear water
but now from the presencewe were opposed by
of great masses of papyrus
which are like palms in
miniature and an inch or
8 or 10 ftfeet high & 1 ½1/2 in diameter - These ^ were laced
together by twining convolulusconvolvulus
so strongly that the weight of us both ^ of us could
not make a path into
the clear water - A path
had indeed been made by
a hippopotamus., but eagerEager
as soon as we reached the
island to look along the
39 43
long vista to clear water I
stepped in ^ to the water & found it took at
me at once up to the neck -

Returning nearly worn
out we preceded up the
Chobe till we came to the
point of departingure ^ of the branch of the
Sanshureh - We then went
in the opposite direction
or down the Chobe though
from the highest trees we
could see nothing but
one vast expense of reed
with here and there a
tree on the islands - This
was a hard daysday's work
and when we came to a
deserted Bayeiye hut on an anthill not
a bit of wood ^ or any thing else could be
got for a fire except for
the grass and sticks of the
dwelling itself - I dreaded the
Tampans so common
in all old huts but without
outside of it we had thousands of
mosquitoes & cold dew began to be deposited so we were
fain to crawl beneath theits
shelter - One is tempted to ask such
I was tempted
to ask in this ^ positions why should we
have ^ we these vermin at all -
And if it is not that we are
Omit. in a world where all are
mutually dependantdependent and
must minister to the
enjoyments of each other
40 44
I found I could adduce no
other argument for bearing
my affliction with patience
Omit After a comfortless night
in damp clothes and in
a damp

We were close to the
reeds and could listen to the
strange sounds which are
often heard there - By day
I had seen water serpents
putting up their heads and
swimming about - There
arewere great numbers of
others which have
made little
"spoors" all
over the plains
in search of
the fishes among the tall grass
of these flooded prairies,
curious birds too jerk
and wriggle among these
reedy masses and we
heard unearthly human
like voices and unearthly
sounds with splash guggle
jupp - as if rare fun were
going on in their to us
uncouth haunts - ^ At one time something
came near ^ us making a
splashing like a canoe or
hippopotamus - Thinking
it to be the Makololo we
got up and listened and shouted
then discharged a gun
several times but it
continued the noise without
intermission for an hour
41 45
After a damp cold night
we set to ^ early in the morning, at our work of
exploring again but left
the pontoon ^ in order to lighten our
labour - The anthills are
here very high some thirty
feet and of a base so
broad ^ that trees grow on
them while the lands
annually flooded have
nothing but grass - From
one of these ^ anthills we discovered
an inlet to the Chobe - And
having gone back for the
pontoon we launched
ourselves on a deep river,
here from eighty to one
hundred yards wide -
GivingI gave my companion
strict struck injunctions to
stick by the pontoon in case
a hippopotamus should
look at us ThisNor was ^ this caution un=necessary
for one came
up at our side
and made a
desperate plunge
off - We had
comepassed over
him - The wave
he made caused
the pontoon to
glide quickly
away from him - weWe paddled
away from midday till
sunset - There was nothing
but a wall of reed on each
bank and we saw noevery
prospect but of spending
a supperless night among
the reed in our float
but just as it was getting
into ourthe short twilight
^ of these parts was commencing we saw the village of
Moremi one of the Makololo
42 46
on the North bank - They The
villagers looked as we may suppose
people do who see a ghost -
And in their figurative way
of speaking said "he has
dropped among us from
the clouds yet came riding
on the back of a hippopotamus
The Makololo thought no
one could cross the Chobe
without their knowledge
but here he drops among us
from w like a bird" -

Next day we returned
in canoes accross the
flooded lands in canoes
and found that in myour
absence the men had
allowed the cattle to wander
^ into a very
small patch
containing to the Tsetse to the West
whichThis carelessness cost
me ten fine large oxen -
And afterAfter remaining a few
days some of the head men
of the Makololo came
down from Linyanti
with a large party of Barotse
to take us accross the river
This they did in fine style swimming
and diving
among the oxen
more like
alligators than
men and by
taking the waggons to pieces
and carrying them accrossacross
on a number of canoes ^ lashed together
We were now among our
friends so going about
43 47
thirty miles to the North in order
to avoid the still flooded
lands on the North of the Chobe
we turned Westwards towards
Linyanti

The whole population of Thethe Town which contains, numbering between
6000 orand 7000 souls, turned
out en masse to see waggons
going they havinghad never
witnessed the phenomenon
before on account of our
we having ^ on the former occasion departed by night
Sekeletu now in power
recievedreceived us in what is
considered royal style, by
setting before us a great
number of pots of beer
or boyaloa the beer of the
country - These are brought
by women and each bearer
takes a good draught of it
the beer, when she sets it down by way
of "tasting" to shewshow ^ that there is no poison

The court herald
an old man who occupied
the post in Sebituane's time
stood up and after some antics,
such as leaping and shouting at
the top of his voice, - roared
out some adulatory sentences
as "DontDon't I see the white man -
DontDon't I see the comrade of
Sebituane - DontDon't I see the
father of Sekeletu "We want sleep"
"Give your son
sleep my lord" &c - &c - " The
perquisites of this man are
the heads of all the cattle
slaughtered by the chief - And he
takes a share of the tribute
before it is taken out of the
Kotla - He is expected to
utter all the proclamations
call assemblies - keep the
Kotla clean and the fire
burning every evening and
when a person is executed
in public he drags away
the body -

I found Sekeletu
a young man of 18 years
of age of a light dark yellow
colour, that of which the
Makololo are so proud as
it distinguishes them much
from the black tribes on
the rivers - He is about five
feet seven ^ in height and neither so
good looking nor of so much
45 49
ability as his father ^ was but is
equally friendly to the English
Sebituane installed his daughter
Mamochisane ^ into the chieftainship ^ long before
his death, but with all his
acuteness the idea of her
having a husband who
should not be her lord did
not seem to enter his mind
He did not wished to make her
his successor probably in
imitation of some of the
negro tribes with whom
he came in contact but
he being of the Bechuana
race could did not look upon the
husband male except as ^ the woman's
lord - So he told her all the
men were hers she might
take any one but keep
none - In fact she might
he thought she might do with
the men what he could
do with the women but these
men had other wives and
according to a saying in the
country "the tongues of women
cannot be governed" They
made her miserable by their
remarks - One man whom
she chose was even called
her wife and aher son the child
of Mamochisane's wife but
the system arrangement was so distasteful
46 50
to Mamochisane herself that
as soon as shSebituane died
she said she never would
consent to govern the
Makololo so long as
she had a brother living
Sekeletu being afraid of another
member of the family 'Mpépe
who had pretensions to the
chieftainship urged his
sister strongly to remain
as she had always been
and allow him to support
her authority by leading
the Makololo when they
went forth to war - Three
days were spent in public
discussion on the point -
It must be And if it be remembered
that throughout the entire
Bechuana country the
greatest respect is paid
to hereditary rank and
relationships with the family
of a chief is as highly valued
as anywhere else in the
world - In meeting a party
of strangers it is not
uncommon to hear the
principal person whisper
to one of his attendants
"Tell him who I am" and
then a ^ half ousincousinship to some
chief is carefully counted on
the fingers -
47 51
The difficulty of this case may
percievedperceived when Mpepe
insinuated held the insinuation that
Sekeletu was not really the ^ lawful son
of Sebituane on account
of his mother having been
the wife of another chief
before ^ her marriage with Sebituane
Mamochisane however
upheld Sekeletu's claims
and at last stood up in the
assembly and addressed him
with a flood of tears - "I have
been a chief only because
my father wished it - I
always wished to be married
and have a family like
other women - You Sekeletu
must be chief and build
up your father's house"
This was a death blow to
the hopes of Mpepe -

As it will enable the
reader to understand the
social and political system
of these people I ^ will add a few
more particulars respecting
Mpepe - Sebituane having
no son to take the leadership
of the "Mopato" of the age
of his daughter chose him
as the nearest male relative
to occupy that post - And
presuming on that relationship
from Mpepe's connection
48 52
with hims ^ family he would attend
to his interests and relieve
him from care he gave
him charge of his cattle
Mpepe removed to the chief
town "Naliele" and took such
effectual charge of all the cattle, that
Sebituane saw he could
only set matters on their
former basisfooting by the severe
measure of Mpepe's execution
MpepeBeing unwilling to do this
and fearing the enchantments
which Mpepe now used,
in a hut built for the
purpose, withby means of a number
of Barotse doctors, and
longing for peaceful retirement
after thirty yearsyears' fighting
he now heard ^ with pleasure of our arrival
at the Lake so he and came
down as far as Sesheke
to meet us - He had an idea
picked up from some of
the numerous strangers
who visited him that white
men had a "pot in their
towns which would burn
up any attacking party" (a cannon)
and ^ he thought if he could
only get this he would
be able to "sleep" the remainedremainder
of his days in peace - This
he hopehoped to obtain from the white man
